author: Adam Shergold for MailOnline
title: Crystal Palace boss Sam Allardyce visits Nando's
text:
Sam Allardyce enjoyed a break from the pressures of Crystal Palace's relegation struggle to attend a book launch - and also have a cheeky Nando's.
The Palace manager was pictured mulling over the menu as he dined alone in the Greenwich branch of the popular Portuguese-themed chicken restaurant.
After choosing his meal, the former England manager happily chatted to young fans as he ate.
Crystal Palace manager Sam Allardyce was pictured dining in the Greenwich Nando's
Allardyce also attended the book launch for DJ and businessman Tony Prince in Mayfair
Allardyce also attended a book launch for DJ and businessman Tony Prince at the Hard Rock Cafe in Mayfair, central London, where he smiled and posed for photographs.
Among those in attendance were legendary jockey Willie Carson and television presenter Lizzie Cundy.
It was a chance for Allardyce to enjoy himself in a tough week that started with his Palace side being thrashed 4-0 at home by his former club Sunderland, a result that pushes them deeper into relegation trouble.
The Palace manager is pictured with Prince, who has released a new autobiography
The Selhurst Park club have still only won once in the league since Allardyce took over just before Christmas and clear-the-air talks were held with the players and chairman Steve Parish this week.
Allardyce made his players report for training at 7am the morning after the Sunderland defeat, forcing them to watch a video of the defeat.
It came after Parish came into the dressing room and laid into the players following the loss to the rock bottom Black Cats.
Allardyce rages during Palace's 4-0 defeat to Sunderland at Selhurst Park last Saturday
The heavy defeat left Palace second bottom in the Premier League table
Speaking ahead of this weekend's match with Stoke, Allardyce said: ‘That was him releasing his frustration on the basis he is a Crystal Palace fan and he wanted to talk to the players.
‘By the end of Sunday morning it was all clear what we’d been through and how we’d let ourselves down.
'We have got to take it on the chin and bounce back and show some fighting spirit.’
